newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: Court upholds aid to German shipbuilder Meerstechnik Werft.
newsitem.headline: Court upholds aid to German shipbuilder Meerstechnik Werft.

text.p: The European Court of First Instance dismissed on Tuesday a challenge from the Danish Shipbuilders' Association against the European Commission's approval of state aid to German shipbuilder Meerstechnik Werft (MTW).
In 1992 the Commission authorized payment of DM 191.2 million in aid to MTW. In 1994, the Commission approved a second tranche of aid to MTW in the amount of DM 406 million.
Danish shipbuilders argued the Commission had no competence to approve the support and that the authorised aid exceeded the limit allowed under EU rules.

The court limited the Commission's duty to explain its decision under the exceptional shipbuilding state aid rules. "For the purposes of assessing the compatibility of operating aid under the exceptional rules introduced by directive 62/68, the Commission's role is limited to checking that the conditions set out in article 10a of the Seventh directive have been observed. In those circumstances, it appears from the case-law that any need to state reasons other than the finding that those conditions are fulfilled is precluded," the court said.
(Court translation into English. Original language of the case: Danish)
